body: With opinions of Rudy Crew's tenure as schools chancellor running the gamut, one common thread emerged yesterday from the reaction to his departure: Here we go again. The political brawl that deposed the chancellor revived bitter memories of the days when it seemed chancellors barely got settled before the ax fell. In the last 30 years, there have
title: THE CHANCELLOR'S OUSTER: THE REACTION; Even Crew's Critics Long for Continuity

body: For years, John Jay High School, on Seventh Avenue near Fourth Street, has been troubled, ranking high among the city's schools in assaults and robberies and low in test scores and graduation rates. John Jay is situated in the prosperous heart of Park Slope, but many parents there never dreamed of sending their children to the school. The local
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; School Board May Try to Take Over Troubled John Jay

body: A four-building, 64-apartment co-op in the Kensington section of Brooklyn that avoided foreclosure seven months ago is back on stable financial footing, ending nearly five years of struggle and enabling shareholders to sell their apartments. Under a reorganization plan approved by the Federal Bankruptcy Court last month, the co-op refinanced its
title: Residential Real Estate; Brooklyn Co-op Makes A Financial Comeback

body: As the years go by you fall into the habit of believing that apples do not taste as sharp as they used to and that candy bars are not as big. They do not, in fact, and they are not; thanks respectively to fruit genetics and marketing margins. But why have my books lost their smell? The smell, when I was 5, of a nubby ''Peter Pan in Kensington
title: You Just Can't Curl Up With a Good Web Site

body: ONE of the companies reporting boffo earnings last week was the Bear Stearns Companies, the nation's fourth-largest publicly traded brokerage firm. A big beneficiary of Wall Street's nonstop party, Bear Stearns reported that net income for the quarter ended June 30 rose 56.2 percent from the comparable period last year. The company even managed to
title: MARKET WATCH; Beneath a Boom Quarter

body: Whitlow Wyatt, a key figure in the Brooklyn Dodgers' celebrated 1941 National League pennant victory and a leading pitcher of the early 1940's, died Friday at a hospital in Carrollton, Ga. Wyatt, who lived in Buchanan, Ga., was 91. After struggling for a decade with three American League teams, Wyatt, a hard-throwing and often intimidating
title: Whitlow Wyatt, 91, Pitcher Who Starred With the Dodgers

body: On a sticky afternoon last week, Adam Schlesinger and Chris Collingwood took a ride to Utopia Parkway. These musicians, who lead the band Fountains of Wayne, had been to that corner of Queens many times, but not often on the physical plane. Mostly they go there within a song, the title track of the band's new album-length invocation of Eastern
title: ON THE STREETS OF NEW YORK WITH/FOUNTAINS OF WAYNE; Urban Minstrels With Roots in Suburbia

body: IF you want to know how New York City takes after an African village, stick around. It has nothing to do with Hillary Rodham Clinton's views on child-rearing. But first, meet Dumisani Kumalo, who became South Africa's chief representative to the United Nations two months ago. The appointment brought him back to this city where he had lived in exile
title: NYC; Urban Streets Carry Echo Of Africa

title: Roberta Oster And Noah Sachs

title: For Class of '99, A Real-Life 'Rent'

body: New York State's highest court decided yesterday to take the teeth out of the state's laws on assault. title: Top Court Decides That, in an Attack, Teeth Are Not a Weapon

body: IN the rest of the country, Long Island tends to have a rather mixed image, concocted from television clips of beautiful beaches, Billy Joel and epic traffic tie-ups on the Long Island Expressway. But nothing has tarnished that image, in the minds of thousands of Americans, as much as another unpleasant element of Island life: stock-market scams.
title: Beaches, Billy Joel and, Oddly, Swindles; The Island Has Become Home to Stock Scams, But Regulators Are Cracking Down

body: NOT long before their daughter Rosetta's wedding, Maria and Louis Guttadauro of Borough Park began looking for a pair of houses to buy alongside each other in the neighborhood where the families could live snugly. title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Borough Park, Brooklyn; For Many Orthodox Jews, a Heartland

body: The Victoria and Albert Museum has not been a happy house in recent years. It was thrown into disarray in 1988 when eight senior curators were dismissed overnight as part of a management shake-up. It was deluged with bad publicity when it introduced admission charges in 1996. And more recently it has been under attack from traditionalists for
title: A London Museum's 'Good Omen'; After Troubles, Approval of an Extension Cheers the V & A
